turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Your Honor, since Rockwell Corp. began construction, the surrounding residential neighborhood has been enshrouded in a cloud of foul-smelling, germ-carrying, pestilent dust. My client is being forced to breathe known carcinogens daily! Other residents are coming forth on a daily basis to add their voices of outrage!

turns.speaker: ANDREW
turns.text: Your Honor, I submit there were no complaints until Counselor began knocking on doors, drumming up business. And the dust, which Counselor refers to, has appeared on only three occasions. Each time it has been examined and the results...

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Innocuous?

turns.speaker: ANDREW
turns.text: Defined by Webster's as harmless.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: I know what it means. Your Honor, imagine how the children in this neighborhood have been made to feel. The pounding of construction ringing in their ears as this skyscraper, a tribute to mankind's greed, grows daily, casting an ominous shadow over their lives, filling them with dread even as they are surrounded in a black, toxic fog, blocking out the sun while poisoning their lungs! And Counselor calls it harmless?!

turns.speaker: ANDREW
turns.text: Client of yours?

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Funny.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Jesus Christ, what happened to you?

turns.speaker: ANDREW
turns.text: I have AIDS.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Whoa-oh!  Sorry, I...

turns.speaker: ANDREW
turns.text: It's okay. Can I sit down?

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Uh, yeah.

turns.speaker: ANDREW
turns.text: New baby?

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: One week old.

turns.speaker: ANDREW
turns.text: Congratulations.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Little baby girl.

turns.speaker: ANDREW
turns.text: Kids are great.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Thanks, Beckett. I'm real excited about it.  What can I do for you?

turns.speaker: ANDREW
turns.text: I was fired by Wyant Wheeler. I plan to bring a wrongful termination suit against Charles Wheeler and his partners.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: You want to sue Wyant Wheeler Hellerman Tetlow and Brown?

turns.speaker: ANDREW
turns.text: Correct. I'm seeking representation.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Continue.

turns.speaker: ANDREW
turns.text: I misplaced an important complaint. That's their story. Want to hear mine?

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: How many lawyers did you go to, before you called me?

turns.speaker: ANDREW
turns.text: Nine.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Continue.

turns.speaker: ANDREW
turns.text: I was diagnosed with AIDS eight months ago. During a bout of pneumonia. I recovered quickly and was back at work in ten days. Since I was doing so well on the AZT, we decided against telling anyone about it.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: We?

turns.speaker: ANDREW
turns.text: My lover and I.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Your... lover?

turns.speaker: ANDREW
turns.text: Miguel Alvarez. We've lived together for nine years.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Continue.

turns.speaker: ANDREW
turns.text: I dove back into work, everything was fine. Until the lesions started...

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Hell, they are staring. What's that shit on your face?

turns.speaker: ANDREW
turns.text: Makeup.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Big trouble.

turns.speaker: ANDREW
turns.text: Charles, I must apologize again, for the Kronos mishap.  It was a scary few minutes around here. Wow. But thank God, the complaint was found. And no damage was done.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: I buy that.

turns.speaker: ANDREW
turns.text: As in, the vegetable?

turns.speaker: ANDREW
turns.text: The law says people with disabilities cannot be terminated, so long as they can perform the duties required by their position...

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Okay, okay... They discover you have this horrible, disgusting, terminal illness, and they panic, for any number of perfectly valid reasons. They're frightened for themselves, their families... Maybe it's the homo angle. Maybe they don't want to rub elbows with someone who's just popped out of the closet with a terminal case of acne. And how do they explain your status to the client for Chrissake?

turns.speaker: ANDREW
turns.text: Joe, from the day I arrived to the day they fired me, I performed consistently, thoroughly and with absolute excellence. And if they hadn't fired me, that's what I'd be doing today.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Okay... They want you out. It's against the law to fire you for having AIDS, so they make you look like a fuck up. Which leads us to the mysterious, lost file.

turns.speaker: ANDREW
turns.text: They sabotaged me.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: I knew you were going to say that. I don't buy it, and I don't see a case.

turns.speaker: ANDREW
turns.text: Look. I know I have a case. If you don't want to take it for personal reasons...

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Correct. I don't.

turns.speaker: ANDREW
turns.text: Thanks for your time.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Beckett? I'm sorry about... what's happened to you. It's a fucking kick in the head.

turns.speaker: ANDREW
turns.text: Don't send flowers, Joe. I'm not dead yet.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Oh, Beckett. How's it goin'?

turns.speaker: ANDREW
turns.text: Fine.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Who'd you get?

turns.speaker: ANDREW
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Find a lawyer?

turns.speaker: ANDREW
turns.text: I'm a lawyer. How's your baby?

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Huh? Oh. Great. She's great.

turns.speaker: ANDREW
turns.text: What's her name?

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Rayisha.

turns.speaker: ANDREW
turns.text: Rayisha. Very nice.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: How did they find out?

turns.speaker: ANDREW
turns.text: One of the partners spotted a lesion on my forehead.

turns.speaker: ANDREW
turns.text: The partner who spotted the lesion, Walter Kenton, used to work for Benton, Myers, in D.C. There's a paralegal there, Maria Torres. She's had lesions on and off for three years. She says it was common knowledge around the office that her lesions were caused by AIDS.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: They didn't fire her?

turns.speaker: ANDREW
turns.text: No. They didn't fire her.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: So Kenton connected the... lesion, <u>and</u> whatever suspicions he had about your personal life... to this woman, Maria... and blew the whistle on you. Suddenly you're losing files, and it's time to let you go. But, up to this point, you've been their Golden Boy, their rising star... Their behavior is... inconsistent.

turns.speaker: ANDREW
turns.text: Thank you.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: There is no relevant precedent.

turns.speaker: ANDREW
turns.text: Arline decision. Supreme Court.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Arline?

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: One more thing, Your Honor...

turns.speaker: ANDREW
turns.text: Any settlement agreement <u>must</u> include, and this is critical, a letter of exoneration, making clear my termination had nothing to do with the quality of my work.

turns.speaker: ANDREW
turns.text: PARRTYY!

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: We're friends of Beckett's.

turns.speaker: ANDREW
turns.text: It's me, you dork.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Beckett. You seem... better. Energized, more alive...

turns.speaker: ANDREW
turns.text: I had a blood transfusion today. I feel great.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: I'm a law suit.

turns.speaker: ANDREW
turns.text: Not bad.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Get it?

turns.speaker: ANDREW
turns.text: Let's find you a drink.

turns.speaker: ANDREW
turns.text: What do you want?

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Beer.  We need to go over your Q and A.

turns.speaker: ANDREW
turns.text: Excuse me, I'm having a goddamn party, is that allright with you?

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Sure. It's fine.

turns.speaker: ANDREW
turns.text: No, we have to do it. But later, allright?

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Thank you.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: You think I'm uncomfortable...

turns.speaker: ANDREW
turns.text: Correct.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: You're right.

turns.speaker: ANDREW
turns.text: You survived your first gay party intact.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Let me tell you something, okay? When you're brought up, like the rest of us, in a place like where I was brought up, there's not a whole lot of discussion about... homosexuals. As a kid, you're taught right away that queers are weird, queers are funny, they're a danger to kids, they're afraid to fight, and they all want to cop your joint. And that pretty much sums up the general thinking out there, if you want to know the truth.

turns.speaker: ANDREW
turns.text: Thank you for sharing that with me, Joe.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Let's review these notes for your testimony. We have a big day on Monday.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: When you refer to Wheeler, call him Charles, to show how you'd been admitted to the inner circle, you were considered one of them.

turns.speaker: ANDREW
turns.text: Uh huh...

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Beckett?

turns.speaker: ANDREW
turns.text: Charles. Okay. Miller?

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: ANDREW
turns.text: Do you... pray?

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Then we establish how Wheeler's boys recruited you after law school...

turns.speaker: ANDREW
turns.text: What have you prayed for?

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: For a healthy baby. For Lisa to make it through the delivery. For the Phillies to get into the playoffs.

turns.speaker: ANDREW
turns.text: There's a possibility I won't be around for the end of this trial.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: I've considered that.

turns.speaker: ANDREW
turns.text: What happens?

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: We proceed, representing your estate.

turns.speaker: ANDREW
turns.text: I've made provisions in my will for some charities. Miguel will need a lawyer. I know it's not your area...

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: I know a good probate lawyer.

turns.speaker: ANDREW
turns.text: Thanks.  Do you like opera?

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Opera?

turns.speaker: ANDREW
turns.text: Want to hear my favorite aria?

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Opera?

turns.speaker: ANDREW
turns.text: I'll look over the Q and A.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: You're ready, don't worry.

turns.speaker: ANDREW
turns.text: Particularly, Charles.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: What impressed you about him?

turns.speaker: ANDREW
turns.text: He was... the kind of person I thought I wanted to be.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: What kind of person is that?

turns.speaker: ANDREW
turns.text: Possessed of an encyclopedic knowledge of the law. A razor sharp litigator, a genuine leader, gifted at bringing out the very best in others. An awesome ability to illuminate the most complex of legal concepts to colleagues, courtrooms, the person on the street.  The kind of person who plays three sets of tennis but doesn't sweat. But underneath the elegant surface, was an adventurous spirit.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Obviously, at this time, you weren't sick.

turns.speaker: ANDREW
turns.text: It's possible I was infected with the HIV virus at that time, but I wasn't diagnosed until several years later.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: You didn't look then, the way you look now?

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: A regular all-American guy?

turns.speaker: ANDREW
turns.text: I suppose you could say that.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Except... you were gay?

turns.speaker: ANDREW
turns.text: I still am.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: In the years you worked at Wyant Wheeler, did you ever tell Charles Wheeler you were gay?

turns.speaker: ANDREW
turns.text: No. I didn't.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Can you explain <u>why</u> you didn't?

turns.speaker: ANDREW
turns.text: You don't bring your personal life into a law firm. You're not supposed to <u>have</u> a personal life, really. Anyway, I did plan to tell Charles, eventually. But then, this thing happened at the tennis club...

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Are you a good lawyer?

turns.speaker: ANDREW
turns.text: I'm an excellent lawyer.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: What makes you an excellent lawyer?

turns.speaker: ANDREW
turns.text: I love the law. I know the law. I excel at practicing it. It's the only thing I've ever wanted to do.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: What do you love about it?

turns.speaker: ANDREW
turns.text: Well... many things. But I think the thing I love the most, is that every once in a while, not that often, but occasionally... you get to be part of justice being done. It's really quite a thrill when that happens.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Do you have any lesions on <u>any</u> part of your body, at this time, that resemble the lesions that were on your face at the time you were fired?

turns.speaker: ANDREW
turns.text: Yes. On my torso.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: If it please the court, I'd like to ask Mr. Beckett to remove his shirt, so that the jury can have an <u>accurate</u> idea of what we're talking about.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Can you see the lesions on your chest in this mirror?

turns.speaker: ANDREW
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Thank you.

turns.speaker: ANDREW
turns.text: What do you call a thousand lawyers chained together at the bottom of the ocean?

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: ANDREW
turns.text: A good start.

turns.speaker: ANDREW
turns.text: Excellent work, Joe. I thank you.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: It was good working with you, Andrew. You're welcome.  Hey. Shouldn't you put that thing back on?

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: I better get home. Lisa and I are having some friends over.

turns.speaker: ANDREW
turns.text: Sure thing.

turns.speaker: ANDREW
turns.text: Thanks for coming by.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: You bet. We'll see you later.

turns.speaker: ANDREW
turns.text: Rach.

turns.speaker: RACHEL
turns.text: I'm late, I have to pick up Amy from her afterschool but I want to talk to you about that Hansen thing.

turns.speaker: ANDREW
turns.text: Catch me later, I'll be here. And tell Amy, I love her painting, it's on my wall.

turns.speaker: RACHEL
turns.text: I thought I was supposed to be covering for you.  God, Andy, you look awful.

turns.speaker: ANDREW
turns.text: Fucking Word Processing lost my Kronos complaint. Which must be filed by fucking five o'clock! If it's late, there's no case...  Every problem has a solution.

turns.speaker: RACHEL
turns.text: What can I do?

turns.speaker: ANDREW
turns.text: Get down to Word Processing. Help Jamey look.

turns.speaker: BELINDA
turns.text: You said earlier you aspired to be the kind of person who had "an adventurous spirit." Is that correct?

turns.speaker: ANDREW
turns.text: Something like that.

turns.speaker: BELINDA
turns.text: Do you take risks?

turns.speaker: ANDREW
turns.text: In my work? Yes. Calculated risks. You have to.

turns.speaker: BELINDA
turns.text: In general. Do you take risks in other areas of your life?

turns.speaker: ANDREW
turns.text: Not unnecessary ones.

turns.speaker: BELINDA
turns.text: Have you ever been to the Apollo Cinema on Sansom Street?

turns.speaker: BELINDA
turns.text: What kind of movies do they show there?

turns.speaker: ANDREW
turns.text: Gay movies.

turns.speaker: BELINDA
turns.text: Gay <u>pornographic</u> movies?

turns.speaker: ANDREW
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: BELINDA
turns.text: Do men have sex with each other in that theater?

turns.speaker: ANDREW
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: BELINDA
turns.text: When? Approximately what year did this event take place?

turns.speaker: ANDREW
turns.text: I guess it was 1984, 85.

turns.speaker: BELINDA
turns.text: Were you aware in 1984 or 1985 that there was a fatal disease out there, called AIDS, and that you could contract it through sexual activity?

turns.speaker: ANDREW
turns.text: It's impossible to know exactly when or how I was infected with HIV.

turns.speaker: BELINDA
turns.text: But you <u>were</u> having anonymous sex in porno theaters in 1984 and 1985?

turns.speaker: ANDREW
turns.text: That happened once. People weren't talking about AIDS then, the way we are now. Or safe sex.

turns.speaker: BELINDA
turns.text: You'd <u>heard</u> of AIDS in 1984, 85?

turns.speaker: ANDREW
turns.text: I'd heard of <u>something</u>. The gay plague, gay cancer, but... we didn't know how you could get it, or that it could kill you.

turns.speaker: BELINDA
turns.text: Do you need a break?

turns.speaker: ANDREW
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: BELINDA
turns.text: While you were employed at Wyant Wheeler, you did everything you could to make sure no one knew you were an active homosexual, correct?

turns.speaker: ANDREW
turns.text: That is <u>not</u> correct. I never lied about it.

turns.speaker: BELINDA
turns.text: Did you keep a picture of your lover on your desk?

turns.speaker: ANDREW
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: BELINDA
turns.text: Do other lawyers at the firm keep pictures of their spouses or fiances on their desks?

turns.speaker: ANDREW
turns.text: Some do. I didn't.

turns.speaker: BELINDA
turns.text: As a homosexual, one is often forced to conceal one's sexuality, is that right?

turns.speaker: ANDREW
turns.text: In some situations.

turns.speaker: BELINDA
turns.text: Isn't it true you have spent your life pretending to be something you're not, so much so that the art of concealment and dishonesty has become second nature to you?!

turns.speaker: ANDREW
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: BELINDA
turns.text: You could have infected him, isn't that right?

turns.speaker: ANDREW
turns.text: Miguel has not been infected. As I said, we weren't aware of AIDS, then, or how it is spread.

turns.speaker: BELINDA
turns.text: Really?

turns.speaker: ANDREW
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: BELINDA
turns.text: You've testified the lesions on your face were visible to the people you worked with, correct?

turns.speaker: ANDREW
turns.text: That's right.

turns.speaker: BELINDA
turns.text: And it's your contention, that when the partners were made aware of the lesions, they jumped to the conclusion you had AIDS and fired you.

turns.speaker: ANDREW
turns.text: Absolutely.

turns.speaker: BELINDA
turns.text: Do you have any lesions on your face at this time?

turns.speaker: ANDREW
turns.text: One. Here, in front of my ear.

turns.speaker: ANDREW
turns.text: By the time I was fired, there were four lesions on my face, much bigger...

turns.speaker: BELINDA
turns.text: Answer the question, please.

turns.speaker: ANDREW
turns.text: No. I can't really see it.

turns.speaker: BELINDA
turns.text: Thank you.

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: Hello?

turns.speaker: ANDREW
turns.text: Hi, Mom. It's me.

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: Andy! This is a nice surprise. How are you, hon?

turns.speaker: ANDREW
turns.text: I'm fine.

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: What's Dr. Gillman say?

turns.speaker: ANDREW
turns.text: Hold on, Mom.  There's no way my client will go along with that.

turns.speaker: ANDREW
turns.text: Gillman says I'm fine. My blood work is excellent. T-cells are up. Just a sec ...  Yes, I think that would alleviate most of our concerns.  My platelets look good too.

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: Are you on one of those conference calls? I hate when you put me on hold.

turns.speaker: ANDREW
turns.text: Hi, Mom. How do you feel on your fortieth anniversary?

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: Ancient. How do you think I feel? Put that thing down and give me a hug.  Andrew, stop! ... He still doesn't listen.

turns.speaker: ANDREW
turns.text: Where's Dad?

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: He's out in his shed showing your uncle his new riding mower.

turns.speaker: ANDREW
turns.text: Mom?

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: All I know is, you got through your diagnosis fine, like a trooper. But when they fired you... you were so devastated, Andy... I don't expect any of my kids to sit in the back of the bus. Fight for your rights.

turns.speaker: ANDREW
turns.text: Thanks, Mom... Dad?

turns.speaker: ANTHEA
turns.text: He was losing weight. He looked kind of tired sometimes. But he was working so hard... Still, I felt something was wrong.  And I can't believe <u>they're</u> saying they didn't notice anything.

turns.speaker: BELINDA
turns.text: Objection.

turns.speaker: BELINDA
turns.text: Miss Burton? Do you still work at Wyant Wheeler?

turns.speaker: ANTHEA
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: BELINDA
turns.text: Were you recently promoted?

turns.speaker: ANTHEA
turns.text: Yes. I'm now in charge of the paralegal department.

turns.speaker: BELINDA
turns.text: Thank you.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Ms. Burton. You're black.

turns.speaker: ANTHEA
turns.text: Is that a question?

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: No. Have you ever felt discriminated against, at Wyant Wheeler?

turns.speaker: ANTHEA
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: In what way?

turns.speaker: ANTHEA
turns.text: Well... One time, Mr. Wheeler's secretary, Lydia, told me Mr. Wheeler had a problem with my earrings.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Your earrings?

turns.speaker: ANTHEA
turns.text: Apparently, Mr. Wheeler felt they were too... "ethnic" is the word she used. She said he would like it if I wore something smaller, less garish, and... more "American."

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: What did you say?

turns.speaker: ANTHEA
turns.text: I said my earrings <u>are</u> American. They're African-American.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Thank you. No more questions.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: And, when lawyers break the law, when this society loses respect for the law, when that day comes, our cherished institutions will be burned to the ground, and our children and grandchildren will live like savages.

turns.speaker: BELINDA
turns.text: Fact. Andrew Beckett performed at a consistently mediocre level. Fact. He made a grievous error on a multi-million dollar lawsuit... Fact. He claims he is the victim of lies and deceit. Fact. Andrew Beckett lied to his employers, going to great efforts to conceal his disease from them. Fact. He was successful in his duplicity. The partners at Wyant Wheeler did <u>not</u> know Andrew Beckett had AIDS when they fired him...

turns.speaker: BELINDA
turns.text: Objection!

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: I'll rephrase.  Did you have anything to do with this file being... misplaced?

turns.speaker: BELINDA
turns.text: Objection!

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: I'll withdraw.  You were aware, when you worked with Maria Torres, that she had AIDS, correct?

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Objection!

turns.speaker: BELINDA
turns.text: I'll withdraw it. Mr. Beckett? Were you living with Miguel Alvarez in 1984 or 1985 when you had your anonymous sexual encounter in the porn theater?

turns.speaker: BELINDA
turns.text: We object, Your Honor. It would unfairly influence the jury.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Your Honor, if Mr. Beckett was forced by his illness to use a wheelchair, would the defense ask him to park it outside? We're talking about AIDS, we're talking about lesions. Let's <u>see</u> what we're talking about.

turns.speaker: DR. ARMBRUSTER
turns.text: You had contact with someone who has AIDS, and you're worried.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: I'm not worried. What are you doing?

turns.speaker: DR. ARMBRUSTER
turns.text: The HIV virus can only be transmitted through the exchange of bodily fluids, namely blood and semen.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Right.

turns.speaker: DR. ARMBRUSTER
turns.text: Leave that.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Yeah, but Doc, isn't it true they keep finding out new things about this disease? So you tell me, today, there's no danger, and I go home, and I hold my baby, and six months from now I hear on the news: "whoops! We were wrong.' You <u>can</u> carry it on your clothes, your skin, and now I've got to worry about my kid. What are you doing?

turns.speaker: DR. ARMBRUSTER
turns.text: We're going to draw blood.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Why are we going to do that?

turns.speaker: DR. ARMBRUSTER
turns.text: Joe. I don't care a whit about your private life.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: You want to give me an AIDS <u>test</u>?!

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: The guy sat in my office! You can't get AIDS that way, right?

turns.speaker: DR. ARMBRUSTER
turns.text: Right.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: It doesn't travel through the air, by breathing, or touching, right?

turns.speaker: DR. ARMBRUSTER
turns.text: Not by touching, or shaking hands, or hugging, using the same toilet... Even kissing someone with AIDS is safe. But it there's something in your past you're worried about...

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Thanks, Doc, but I don't need an AIDS test. Are you crazy? But thanks for the information. Really.

turns.speaker: DR. ARMBRUSTER
turns.text: A homosexual encounter.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Get real.

turns.speaker: DR. ARMBRUSTER
turns.text: Unprotected sex with a prostitute.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Uh.... No. Not really.

turns.speaker: DR. ARMBRUSTER
turns.text: Or unprotected sex with someone you didn't know very well, any time during the last twelve years.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Andrew Beckett represented your company in a lawsuit in 1990, is that correct?

turns.speaker: LAIRD
turns.text: Wyant Wheeler represented us.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: But, Andrew Beckett was in charge of litigation for the suit.

turns.speaker: LAIRD
turns.text: That's correct.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Were you pleased with his work?

turns.speaker: LAIRD
turns.text: We were satisfied.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Mr. Laird, when I approached you about being a witness at this trial, and you agreed, you gave sworn testimony in a deposition. Is that correct?

turns.speaker: LAIRD
turns.text: That's correct.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: According to the deposition, you said you were "thrilled, impressed, overwhelmed" by the quality of Andrew Beckett's work. Do you remember saying that?

turns.speaker: LAIRD
turns.text: I may have said something like that. But that's not how I feel at this moment.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Okay, Mr. Laird. Explain this to me like I'm a four year old: Did Andrew Beckett win your lawsuit for you or not?

turns.speaker: LAIRD
turns.text: We won.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Did that thrill, impress and overwhelm you?

turns.speaker: LAIRD
turns.text: It satisfied me.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: It's a long way between being overwhelmed and being satisfied. A cheeseburger may be satisfying whereas caviar and champagne and roast duck and baked Alaska for dessert might be considered overwhelming. Do you agree?

turns.speaker: LAIRD
turns.text: I might.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Five months ago you characterized Andrew Beckett as caviar and now you're calling him a cheeseburger. Your standards have shifted a great deal, and I'd like to know why you've changed your mind.

turns.speaker: LAIRD
turns.text: Since that time I've devoted more thought to the subject, and that's how I feel now.

turns.speaker: WHEELER
turns.text: Andy. Before we begin, I'd just like to say: everyone in this room is your friend.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: You're in trouble.

turns.speaker: WHEELER
turns.text: Let's put it this way, Andy: your place in the future of this firm is no longer secure.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: In a word, yes.

turns.speaker: WHEELER
turns.text: We don't think it's fair to keep you here, where your future is limited. But we wish you luck, Andy, all the luck in the world.

turns.speaker: WHEELER
turns.text: And I hate to rush you out of here, but...

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: But he's got lots of other people's lives to ruin...

turns.speaker: WHEELER
turns.text: ... we've got a committee meeting.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Explain to me, if you can, Mr. Wheeler, explain this to me like I'm a ten year-old. This trial is not about a disease, is that what you're saying? <u>Not</u> about your understandable, if unfounded, fear of catching AIDS through casual contact with someone who has it? You're saying, this trial is about Andrew Beckett's character. Am I getting this right?

turns.speaker: WHEELER
turns.text: Yes, character. To the extent that it affects a person's ability to do a great job.

turns.speaker: WHEELER
turns.text: Sometimes it seems like society is <u>run</u> by these kinds of people.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: What kind of people?

turns.speaker: WHEELER
turns.text: People who want to bend the rules...

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Good school. What year?

turns.speaker: YOUNG MAN
turns.text: Second.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Great.

turns.speaker: YOUNG MAN
turns.text: Would you like to have a drink with me? I just finished a game, I could use a beer.  I don't pick up people in drug stores every day.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Whoa, whoa, whoa, whoa... do you think... ? You think <u>I'm</u>...  ... gay?

turns.speaker: YOUNG MAN
turns.text: Aren't you?

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: What's the matter with you? Do I look gay to you?

turns.speaker: YOUNG MAN
turns.text: Do I look gay to you? Relax.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Relax? I ought to kick your faggoty little ass for you!

turns.speaker: YOUNG MAN
turns.text: Take it as a compliment. Geesh.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Don't you know this is exactly the kind of bullshit that makes people hate you guys?

turns.speaker: YOUNG MAN
turns.text: Fuck you! You want to kick my ass? You want to try?  Asshole.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: You're the asshole, buddy.

turns.speaker: YOUNG MAN
turns.text: Get a life.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: You load the film... ? No, on this side... or this side? Don't move the baby!

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: Give me the camera, Joe.

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: You have a problem with gays, Joe.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Not especially.

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: How many gays do you know?

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: How many do you know?

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: Lots.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Who?

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: Karen Berman. Aunt Teresa. My cousin Tommy who lives in Rochester. Eddie Meyers from the office. Joe Cantwell, he's one of the partners. His lover, Greg. Stanley, the guy who's putting in our kitchen cabinets.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Your Aunt Teresa is gay? That beautiful, sensuous woman is a... <u>lesbian</u>?

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: Duh...

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Since when?

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: Probably since she was born.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Allright. I admit it: I'm prejudiced. I don't want to work with a homosexual. You got me.

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: Okay, Joe...

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: I mean, two guys, doing the horizontal thing? I don't get it. Don't they get confused? "Is that mine? I thought it was yours." Hey, call me old fashioned, call me conservative... I think maybe you have to be a man to get just how nauseating the whole basic idea really is.

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: Fine, Joe.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: And the way they work out, pumping up, so they can be macho and faggot at the same time... I can't <u>stand</u> that shit. Now I'm being totally honest with you.

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: That's perfectly clear.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Would you take a client if you were constantly thinking: "I hope this guy doesn't touch me. I don't even want him to <u>breathe</u> on me?"

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: Don't know, Joe.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Is there some kind of expression I've picked up from Beckett?! Some kind of fairy attitude I've unconsciously adopted?! Am I walking different?! Some kind of vocal thing?! Have I picked up some kind of homo <u>vibe</u>?!

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: Have you changed your aftershave?

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Very funny. I had a box of Pampers under my arm for Chrissake!

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: Joe?

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Yeah... ?

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: Two men making love... ? Now tell me again... <u>why</u> is that disgusting?

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Lisa, c'mon. One guy sticking his dick in another guy's mouth? It's disgusting.

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: Okay, so... help me with this one, Joe... Is it disgusting for someone to put his dick into someone's mouth? Or, is it disgusting for someone to take a dick into <u>their</u> mouth?

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Great, Lisa. Thank you.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Did I ever tell you, I hate costume parties?

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: My lettuce is wilting.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: I'll see you in an hour, max.

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: Night, honey.

turns.speaker: MRS. FINLEY
turns.text: Right.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Why didn't you cross at the crosswalk?

turns.speaker: MRS. FINLEY
turns.text: Why should I?

turns.speaker: MRS. FINLEY
turns.text: Yeah. Do I have a case?

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Of course you have a case! Now, I want you to go with my assistant, Iris, and fill out some forms. She'll tell you about our fee arrangement.  Mrs. Finley? Any back pain since the accident? Dizziness? Nightmares?

turns.speaker: MRS. FINLEY
turns.text: Now that you mention it...

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Tell Iris all about it.  Take good care of Mrs. Finley, Iris.  Beckett, come in.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Whoa, whoa...  What do you expect them to say, you're Alan Dershowitz?

turns.speaker: KENTON
turns.text: A trial takes <u>time</u>, Beckett. Do you know what I'm saying?

turns.speaker: KENTON
turns.text: Anywhere from two weeks, to several months.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Any women on board?

turns.speaker: KENTON
turns.text: Not when I was in the Navy.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: So during those long voyages, months at a time, out to sea, no women in sight, a hundred, hardworking, robust, young men, in the prime of their life, at the peak of their natural appetites, desires, their god- given, hormonal <u>instincts</u>... Anything going on?

turns.speaker: KENTON
turns.text: Going on... like...?

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Like... two sailors playing hide the salami.

turns.speaker: KENTON
turns.text: Yeah. But we took care of him.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: How did you do that?

turns.speaker: KENTON
turns.text: We stuck his head in the latrine, after ten of us had used it.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: You taught him a lesson.

turns.speaker: KENTON
turns.text: Yes, we did.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Like firing Andrew Beckett taught <u>him</u> a lesson?

turns.speaker: KENTON
turns.text: <u>She</u> didn't try to conceal it.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: So you are aware of the difference between a lesion and a bruise, is that correct?

turns.speaker: KENTON
turns.text: I <u>know</u> the difference. That doesn't mean I'm always able to recognize the difference.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: But didn't you avoid contact with Ms. Torres, after you found out she had AIDS? She says you acted repulsed by her and you avoided her, is that correct?

turns.speaker: KENTON
turns.text: I felt, and still feel, nothing but the deepest sympathy and compassion for people like Maria, who have contracted this terrible disease through no fault of their own.

turns.speaker: JUDGE GARNETT
turns.text: Attorney for the plaintiff?

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Joseph Miller, Your Honor. Macready and Shilts Legal Services.

turns.speaker: JUDGE GARNETT
turns.text: I've seen your television commercials. "If you or anyone you know has been injured through the fault of others... It should say, "through the <u>negligence</u> of others."

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: I'll take that under consideration, Your Honor.

turns.speaker: JUDGE GARNETT
turns.text: On behalf of the defendants?
